para.p: In this note I’m just presenting the proof of Denjoy’s theorem in Michael Brin and Garrett Stuck’s Introduction to dynamical systems, Cambridge University Press, 2002.

Let

S 1
/ R Z

→

S 1
by

.

We say that a homeomorphism
: f
→
S 1
S 1
is orientation preserving if it lifts to an increasing homeomorphism
: F
→ R R
:
=
∘ π F
∘ f π
.

The rotation number of an orientation preserving homeomorphism
f
is defined by

Math.text: rho * f = (limit _ (n to infinity))@((F ^ n * x - x) / n)

para.p:
One proves that this is independent both of the lift
F
of
f
and the point
∈ x R
. Some facts about the rotation number: it is an invariant of topological conjugacy, and
⁢ ρ
( f )
is rational if and only if
f
has a periodic point. A periodic point is
∈ x
S 1
such that
=
⁢
f n
( x )
x
for some
≥ n 1
.

There are some lemmas in Chapter 7 that I don’t want to write out. The important theorem that we’re going to use without proof is that if
: f
→
S 1
S 1
is an orientation preserving homeomorphism that is topologically transitive with irrational rotation number
⁢ ρ
( f )
, then
f
is topologically conjugate to
R
⁢ ρ
( f )
. This reduces our problem to showing that a map is topologically transitive.
We will use the following lemma in the proof of Denjoy’s theorem.

Math.text: Var@(g) >= absolute-value@(logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * x) - logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * y))

≥
the sum coming from any particular partition or a subset of that partition.

Math.text: Var@(g) >= ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(absolute-value@(g * f ^ k * y - g * f ^ k * x)) >= absolute-value@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(g * f ^ k * y) - g * f ^ k * x) = absolute-value@(logarithm * ((product _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(f ^ prime * f ^ k * y) - logarithm * ((product _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(f ^ prime * f ^ k * x)) = absolute-value@(logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * x) - logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * y))

absolute-value@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(g * f ^ k * y) - g * f ^ k * x)
absolute-value@(logarithm * ((product _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(f ^ prime * f ^ k * y) - logarithm * ((product _ (k = 0)) ^ (n - 1))@(f ^ prime * f ^ k * x))
absolute-value@(logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * x) - logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * y))

para.p: Now we can prove Denjoy’s theorem.

p.text:
If
: f
→
S 1
S 1
is a
C 1
diffeomorphism that is orientation preserving, that has irrational rotation number
⁢ ρ
( f )
, and whose derivative
:
f ′
→
S 1
R
has bounded variation, then
f
is topologically conjugate to
R
⁢ ρ
( f )
.

para.p:
Suppose by contradiction that
f
is not topologically transitive. It’s a fact proved in Chapter 7 of Brin and Stuck that this implies that
⁢ ω
( x )
is perfect and nowhere dense, and is independent of the point
x
. (Recall that
=

( x )

≥ n 1
¯

≥ i n
⁢
f i
( x )
.) It follows that there is an interval
= I
( a , b )
in its complement.

The intervals
⁢
f n
( I )
,
∈ n Z
, are pairwise disjoint, for otherwise
f
would have a periodic point. Let
μ
be Haar measure on
S 1
. Then

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(mu * f ^ n * I) less= 1

Math.text: mu * f ^ n * I + mu * f ^ (- n) * I = (integral _ I)@(f ^ n ^ prime * x * differential-d@(x)) + (integral _ I)@(f ^ (- n) ^ prime * x * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ I)@((f ^ n ^ prime * x + f ^ (- n) ^ prime * x) * differential-d@(x)) >= (integral _ I)@(square-root@(f ^ n ^ prime * x * f ^ (- n) ^ prime * x) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ I)@(square-root@(exponential@(logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * x * f ^ (- n) ^ prime * x))) * differential-d@(x)) >= (integral _ I)@(square-root@(exponential@(- absolute-value@(logarithm@(f ^ n ^ prime * x * f ^ (- n) ^ prime * x)))) * differential-d@(x)) >= (integral _ I)@(square-root@(exponential@(- Var@(g))) * differential-d@(x)) = exponential@(- (1 / 2) * Var@(g)) * mu * I
mu * f ^ n * I + mu * f ^ (- n) * I

para.p:
Since
>
⁢ μ
( I )
0
this implies that
=

∈ n Z
⁢ μ
(
⁢
f n
( I )
)
∞
, a contradiction. Therefore
f
is topologically transitive, and so it is topologically conjugate to the
R
⁢ ρ
( f )
. ∎

It is indeed necessary that
f ′
has bounded variation. Brin and Stuck give an example on p. 161 that they attribute to Denjoy: for any irrational number
∈ ρ
( 0 , 1 )
, there is a nontransitive orientation preserving
C 1
diffeomorphism of
S 1
with rotation number
ρ
. The only condition of Denjoy’s theorem that isn’t satisfied here is that
f ′
have bounded variation.
